message_1: A teacher wants to organize a project for their class of 20 students. The project requires each student to work in a group of exactly 4 students. How many groups can the teacher form?
message_2:
To determine the number of groups the teacher can form, we can use the combination formula, which is:

C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!)

where n is the total number of students, k is the number of students in each group, and ! denotes the factorial of a number.

In this case, n = 20 and k = 4.

C(20, 4) = 20! / (4!(20-4)!)

C(20, 4) = 20! / (4!16!)

C(20, 4) = (20 × 19 × 18 × 17 × 16!)/(4 × 3 × 2 × 1 × 16!)

C(20, 4) = (20 × 19 × 18 × 17)/(4 × 3 × 2 × 1)

C(20, 4) = (2 × 10 × 19 × 3 × 6 × 17)

C(20, 4) = 4845

So, the teacher can form 4845 different groups of 4 students each.
